B00004Z459|1.0|I originally had a one-star review on here earlier, but I thought that review kind of sucked, so I'll write a better review.<br /><br />In the 7th grade, I was a huge Linkin Park fan, and I only got my music off of the radio. I did not know about true metal about that time. All I listened to was nu-metal, pop-punk and alternative rock. Times change for everyone. Those days are over. And I am done with Linkin Park.<br /><br />Linkin Park are one of the most overrated groups and untalented groups out there. I listened to this CD four years later and discovered that this is garbage. I usually don't care for lyrics in my music, but with redundant lyrics like \\"Shut up when I'm talking to you\\" and \\"I tried so hard and got so far\\", you know this music was made for teenagers. I am 16 years old, but I listen to artists about 1,000,000,000 times more creative than Linkin Park.<br /><br />Machine Head tends to be one of the artists hacked from on this record, and I'm talking about \\"Burning Red\\" era Machine Head. It's \\"The Burning Red\\", but it's made corporate and watered down with flooded turntables and terrible vocals. This is my description of this sad excuse for a record.<br /><br />The songs really aren't that great. Turntables flood the material over. Incubus and Deftones use turntables in their music, but they don't use them as much as Linkin Park. The vocals reminded me of something that you would hear from the average boy band. I don't know if I'm just being ironic, but during the softer parts in \\"Crawling\\", Chester sounds like the singer of Savage Garden. I may be sounding like an idiot, but this is MY review. \\"One Step Closer\\" is extremely overplayed, but not as much as \\"In The End\\", which STILL gets played on the pop radio stations ad nauseum.<br /><br />It's time to try something better, people. Linkin Park is just a corporate MTV puppet that sells themselves out terribly. Buy ANYTHING EXCEPT THIS (except garbage by Good Charlotte and Limp Bizkit).
B0007YMUZW|4.0|It was hard to predict what form Cold Roses would take. Since the collapse of Ryan Adams' pioneering Americana band Whiskeytown, he's made the forlorn Heartbreaker, the classic rock Gold, the abrasive Rock 'n' Roll and the disturbing Love is Hell EPs. During this period <br />he found the time to play in The Finger, a punk rock side project with Jesse Malin, the metal band Warewolf, and record three as yet unreleased albums. <br /> <br />Cold Roses opens with 'Magnolia Mountain', a track that immediately places the listener back in familiar territory.  Unlike the brattish stylings of Rock 'n' Roll, or the amphetamine fuelled Love is Hell sessions, it is awash with acoustic guitar and pedal steel.  Soon, the whole band is jamming and playing loose, lending the songs a live barroom feel.  Count-ins are included and before one number Ryan shouts, \\"You better believe me L-U-V!  Give me a beer!\\"  On this evidence, it sounds as if he is back in the alt country saddle where he belongs.  <br /> <br />'Sweet Illusions' and 'Let It Ride' are as catchy as anything that Ryan has recorded before.  'Meadowlake Street' is sublime, starting with just his vocals and finger picked guitar, but building to a towering colossus that U2 would be proud of.  'Beautiful Sorta' is old school rock and blues straight out of the 70s, and 'Now That You're Gone' is a melancholy lament that would be at home on Heartbreaker. It has the same dustbowl sound of Gram Parsons, Neil Young and The Band. <br /> <br />On Cold Roses, Ryan has stopped pretending that he's a cool NYC kid, gone back to his Whiskeytown roots, harmonica, honky tonk-keys and all.  It might have been a stronger album with fewer tracks, but small doses are not Ryan's style.  As it stands, Cold Roses is a welcome return to form.
B000929AJQ|5.0|I may be jumping the gun with a 5 star rating, but With Teeth appears to be another feather in Trents increasingly large cap. <br /> <br />One thing that is missing from this album compared to NIN's earlier work (partricularly the Fragile) is the notable lack of experimental tracks. To some people this is what makes Nine Inch Nails, but for the less hardcore fans this could prove to be a blessing in disguise for the album is a lot more accessible than previous works. <br /> <br />Standout tracks include the opening \\"All the love in the world\\" and \\"Everyday is Exactly The Same\\" which follow in the vein of \\"Hurt\\" & \\"Something I Can Never Have\\" as the albums slow melodies. The single \\"Bite The Hand That Bleeds\\" is by my opinion not one of the stronger songs on the album, but does have a poppy catchy feel to it. The best song for me is \\"Only\\" which has the potential 2 become a club classic, if it ever gets the airplay it deserves.

1577311523|1.0|Many years ago I went through a spell of compulsive thinking that was particularly acute and painful. One day, while I was in the grip of these tormenting thoughts, I walked into my garden. Suddenly I saw my cat jump on a small rodent. I immediately rushed to the rescue of the tiny animal. After I had delivered it and given my cat a good but useless scolding, I remembered my previous painful engagement with thought. To my utter astonishment, the problem and the thinking that went with it-- or rather had created it--had totally disappeared!<br /><br />This simple anecdote may serve to illustrate the main error of Eckhart Tolle's teachings. The mournful round of thoughts had come to an abrupt end not because I had tried to stop it, but because there was a sudden, unpremeditated gap in it, caused by an unexpected incident that had required all my attention. Now what Eckhart wants you to do is to bring about this change through effort, and he gives you tricks to achieve it. All this obviously implies a motive (putting an end to an unpleasant state), compulsion and time, all of which indicate that thought--the cause of all the mischief and misery--is still active. Instead of identifying with thought or resisting the now, what one is now doing is trying to disidentify oneself from it or to say \\"yes\\" to the now. This is another game by exactly the same actor.<br /><br />Therefore this path is not going to lead you very far. It is as simple as that.<br /><br />The book itself is written in very simple English and in a question and answer format. I noted that the author claims that his words, specially the repetitive parts of the book, can draw you into the nothingness from which they came. Maybe. What I have found is that the Power of Now is mostly very vapid prose full of cheap and hackneyed notions spiced up with a few Gospel and Zen quotes. The aim seems to be the \\"end of suffering\\", which makes enlightenment a kind of Ultimate Prozac. The author insists that it is something that is \\"felt\\" and speaks of the unending bliss resulting from residing in Being. All this seems too superficial, too epidermic to be true. And creates tremendous expectation. No wonder people start making superhuman efforts to be awake after reading the book. Unfortunately, when you try to force thinking to stop, it comes back at your throat with a vengeance. Remember the anecdote at the beginning of this review.<br /><br />If you are a serious spiritual seeker, I recommend J.Krishnamurti instead of E.T. See my own review of \\"Total freedom\\" for more information.<br /><br />Finally, let me tell you something: Eckhart Tolle sells photographs of his uninspiring face on his website. Five dollars for a view of his congested face absorbed in meditation or smiling at the disciple/customer. Isn't that enough to show the vulgarity of the whole thing?<br /><br />Move on, truth is not to be found here.is something that is \\"felt\\" and speaks of the unending bliss resulting from residing in Being. All this seems too superficial, too epidermic to be true. And creates tremendous expectation. No wonder people start making superhuman efforts to be awake after reading the book. Unfortunately, when you try to force thinking to stop, it comes back at your throat with a vengeance. Remember the anecdote at the beginning of this review.  <br /> <br />If you are a serious spiritual seeker, I recommend J.Krishnamurti instead of E.T. See my own review of \\"Total freedom\\" for more information.  <br /> <br />Finally, let me tell you something: Eckhart Tolle sells photographs of his uninspiring face on his website. Five dollars for a view of his congested face absorbed in meditation or smiling at the disciple/customer. Isn't that enough to show the vulgarity of the whole thing?  <br /> <br />Move on, truth is not to be found here.

0312983867|5.0|Stephanie Plum is at it again, in this eighth book by author Janet Evanovich. Hard Eight, continues the adventures of the wanna-be-intrepid bounty hunter Plum tries to find seven-year-old Annie Solder and her mother, Evelyn, who have disappeared. Evelyn's estranged husband, Steven is the shady owner of a dive bar, and he, too, is looking for his ex-wife and daughter, but they aren't the only ones.<br /><br />Plum takes on the case as a favor to her mother's neighbor, a woman she grew up living next door to, but whom she has few ties. Finding a missing child is hardly work for a Fugitive Apprehension Agent, but Stephanie feels obligated, as she learns that a child custody bond was signed by Annie's grandmother, and if the child and her mother are not recovered, she could lose her house.<br /><br />As she digs deeper into the case she discovers that, as always, somebody is angry at Stephanie Plum and wants her to disappear-for good. This book's villain is nastier than most, as he will stop at nothing to get what he wants from Evelyn and Annie. The only problem is, Plum has no idea what that might be, despite the fact he is convinced she knows.<br /><br />With her life on the line, Plum searches for the elusive Evelyn, and is forced to join up with the mysterious and sexy Ranger, who scares her to death because she is so attracted to him. She also needs the help of her on-again, off-again fianc&eacute; Trenton cop Joe Morelli. Tagging along with Stephanie is the irrepressible Lula, a former prostitute turned file clerk who fancies herself a bounty hunter, and a new sidekick, Evelyn's lawyer/Laundromat manager, who resembles the Pillsbury Doughboy.<br /><br />Evanovich has done it again, creating incredibly real characters, including the two sexy men who are vying for Stephanie's attention. You don't know which one to root for, which says volumes for Evanovich's writing ability. As usual, the humor is sharp and funny, in particular a scene where the hapless Plum is attacked by a gaggle of geese who want her Crackerjacks.<br /><br />Whether bemoaning her bad hair days, or losing her fourth set of handcuffs in a week, Plum manages to keep plugging along and keep the reader veering between horror and humor.<br /><br />I highly recommend Hard Eight, and encourage anyone who has not read the Stephanie Plum novels before to go back and start at the beginning. It's worth it!acked by a gaggle of geese who want her Crackerjacks. <br /> <br />Whether bemoaning her bad hair days, or losing her fourth set of handcuffs in a week, Plum manages to keep plugging along and keep the reader veering between horror and humor. <br /> <br />I highly recommend Hard Eight, and encourage anyone who has not read the Stephanie Plum novels before to go back and start at the beginning. It's worth it! <br /> <br />

When he did a re-release of \\"The Fragile,\\" I didn't think he'd ever come out with a new album. \\"With Teeth\\" certainly is new, but it's not good. \\"Bite the Hand that Feeds\\" is the only \\"hit\\" that's going to come off of this CD or be played in the clubs. With Reznor, you can usually count on thought-provoking lyrics or at least some complex, thrashing tunes. \\"With Teeth\\" is without both of these. The music and lyrics are kind of light and lilty like those of, dare I say it, Elvis Costello or Billy Corigan. It says a lot, but it doesn't make a real point. Re-grouped groups like Velvet Revolver and Audioslave are at least staying closer to their indie-alt roots. If you want something to remind you of the good tunes from the late 80s, get Beck's new one.
B000002Q7Y|4.0|Kansas \\"Power\\" is full of really Good Music !! Early fans of Kansas will want to dismiss it. But they are wrong !! <br />Kansas is and always will be Kansas. No matter what line up they use. Steve Morse was a solid replacement for Livgren and it can easily be heard. Combine his talents with the likes of Ehart,Williams,Greer and Walsh and you have \\"Power\\"!! <br />Speaking of Steve Walsh, I want to say that in my humble opinion he is by far one of the best vocalist in Progressive Rock. He is very underated. The same could be said of drummer Phil Ehart who is a technical wizard behind his kit. <br />Phil Ehart is the executive producer behind this album which was recorded at the Castle \\"Franklin Tennesse\\" in 1986. The London Philharmonic parts were recorded at the famous Abbey Road studios. This Cd has been digitally remastered and provides the finest in audio quality. So \\"Play It Loud\\" for full effect. <br />The cover art is also worth a mention. It is stupendous !! <br />The song writing credits go to both Walsh and Morse who collaborate wonderfully. Lyrically speaking, Kansas knows the importance of combining Great lyrics about Life and Life situations with musical mastery. <br /> <br />The Powerful opening track: <br />Silhouettes In Disguise -- fast hard rocker. Driving guitar,bass and drums. A catchy sing along chorus and Walsh's trademark keyboards. A Morse speed metal guitar solo included. <br /> <br />Power -- I love the lyrics to this one along with the catchy chorus. Walsh delivers fine vocals and Phil Ehart backs him up with some tasty drum fills. <br /> <br />All I Wanted -- a typical Kansas Ballad. Excellent vocals !! The keyboard arrangements enhance the orchestral feel to this song. <br /> <br />Secret Service -- {my least favorite} gives off a very robotic vibe due in large part to the electric sounding drums and musical phrasing. You can hear the stomping bass and keyboard patterns of a robot on the prowl for our very souls. Is it the secret service ?Out to get us \\"Beware\\"!! <br /> <br />Were Not Alone Anymore -- Heavy Steve Morse influence. Fast uptempo progressive rock shuffle. Featuring great thumping bass guitar patterns,dynamic drumming and fast furious guitars. <br /> <br />Musicato -- an instrumental that starts with a drum cadence style roll pattern added to some matching keyboards and bass. Phil Ehart gives us a taste of his double bass drum technique. Bass guitar is awesome. This song also features lots of intricate breaks and musical interlude passages. <br /> <br />Taking In The View -- a beautiful song with lovely acoustic guitars and a boys choir trio in the middle section of the song. There is a free flowing mix of emotion within. <br /> <br />Three Pretenders -- another Kansas power hitter. Williams is showcased with his excellent rhythmic chord strumming. Morse offers us his version of a fast explosive guitar solo. Very good background vocals. <br /> <br />Tomb 19 -- straight ahead rocker with a commercial flare to it. This should have recieved some air play. Bassist Greer cuts loose with some creative octave style fingering. Check out Eharts ride cymbal pattern and he also provides the ending with impressive drum fills. <br /> <br />Cant Cry Anymore -- a Kansas style ballad with Walsh at the helm. <br />A sad song about broken relationships. Walsh's heartfelt vocals let us know that nobodys to blame, it just happens. The Philharmonic orchestra completes this finale. <br />Sometimes we all just  \\"Cant Cry Anymore\\" <br /> <br />It's got power and feeling. Kansas \\" POWER \\"

B000068FY0|5.0|OK, I love this album; I first heard it as a 15-year-old in 1975, and played it endlessly - it's THAT album for me.     Those of you who only know the band from Breakfast In America are missing something important. This is one of the most perfectly constructed, played and produced albums of the 70's. It bears comparison with Dark Side of the Moon without question: and it is a great deal less angst-ridden.     Get this, and listen to it. \\"Breakfast\\" is light, sugary-sweet by comparison. From the opening, unforgettable harmonica solo, to the fading chords of the last track, this is proper music, played for intelligent listeners, and not with the radio or the charts in mind. All the songs are through-composed, all impeccably arranged and played, and that production is astonishing. Listen to the drums on 'If Everyone Was Listening'. Or the Wurlitzer solo on 'School'. Or... I could go on and on. For the perfect blend of musicianship, accessibility and adherence to exacting standards, it is very, very hard to find anything that could compete with this record.
B0008ISM40|4.0|I've just listened to this album a few times in my car, then on my PC while browsing around and wasting time, and I just finished intently listening to it several more times.  I believe this album will have things both long-time NIN fans and casual listeners will enjoy.    I've been a fan of NIN since I was first exposed to Pretty Hate Machine by a friend in High School.  A year or so after hearing that, Downward Spiral was released.  I don't believe any musician made me feel the way Reznor did with his words and aggressive music, punctuated by the occassional slow and dark melody.  The songs spoke to my feelings of being outcast and incomplete.    Then Fragile was released while I managed a record store in St. Louis.  Despite the hype, and many hard core fans being dissappointed, I liked it.  I felt it was a more mature outlook on things, it seemed that Trent and I had both done some growing up.    With Teeth sounds much like Fragile musically, with moments of soft industrial rythm to aggressive percussion. However the lyrics grabbed me to a greater degree than the Fragile had.  Though the music is different, some of the lyrics remind me of Pretty Hate Machine. (I said SOME, others remind me of Fragile..don't freak out on me) Many of the songs speak of love (not the flowers and puppy kind) and how it affects you.  And like the good old days of a pimple-faced me holed up in my bedroom listening to NIN, the songs made me reflect on myself and how I felt.  NO album has been able to do this to me in years.  I've recently started a graveyard shift job, still work a few hours in another job, and been planning my wedding.  Over the past year of stress and drama, this album has come up from under the noise to really get to me.  I honestly feel more understanding of myself after hearing Trent's words.  And that's no exaggeration.    The songs 'The Hand that Feeds' and 'Every Day is Exactly the Same' both have a distinctive feeling of being isolated and cut off.  They reallyspoke to me at this point in my life. 'The Hand' in particular has an old style throw-your-fist-in-the-air rebelliousness without regressing to something that makes me feel like a kid.    The songs that have an honest reference to love, like 'All the Love in the World' and 'Sunspots', are very good.  They are the kind of love songs that I like to hear.  They reflect the more mature Trent that has grown up with us since Downward Spiral.  What?  Industrial love songs?  Yes they exist and nobody does it better than Trent.  His matured love songs from Fragile and With Teeth make me reflect on my fiance.  Trent's songs of love are honest and realistic.  They remind you that person has a profound effect on you for the better.    Some of the songs sounded a little poppy at first, 'Only' in particular.  However they grew on me, mostly because of the lyrics.    The last song 'Right Where it Belongs' is a slow and dark piano-accented finale.   I feel it has some of the best lyrics to come from Reznor in a while.  'Every Day is Exactly the Same' is a runner up for lyrics that moved me the most.    All in all, this NIN album has a bit for everyone.  It has pulsing industrial anthems, aggressive rock, and dark melodies that will move you.  However, if you can get past whatever you think about the music, whether you wish it was like the older NIN or more like the Fragile, the lyrics are what sold me on this album.  NIN has always been the best industrial band, not just because the music was provacative, but because Trent's messages were always there and at the core of it all.    Put everything aside and listen to what Trent has to say, he might more know about how you feel than you think he does.

They all sing, they have *gasp* Good lyrics, funny and angry at the same time, amazing drumming, bass and guitar, The Sheer joy of hearing metal sung in a falsetto, the attention to detail, the courage it takes to make a song like \\"radio video\\", with hints of polka and reggae, while staying metal. The Eastern influence on the music... No one sounds like System, and Even if they tried, No one would pull it off. This band is truly original, and I have a feeling they'll be sticking around for while, long after hoobastank dies. Which cant come soon enough. I do have an issue with how it was mixed though. The drums are barely there! John is a very good drummer, but it doesnt show like it did on toxicity, or thier self titled. There needs to be a remastered edition, with louder drums  My only real complaint is that, just like you have heard, Daron seems to take control. While he holds up amazing backing vocals on thier first three, and then some, He goes a little overboard here. Serj is clearly a much better vocalist, and should stick to lead. I hope we see more of him on Hypnotize. But from the thrash metal of \\"This Cocaine Makes Me Feel Like I'm On This Song\\"to the death metal polka ska of \\"Radio Video\\" to the best song on the album ( in this humble teenagers opinion) The soaring \\"Question!\\", System proves that they are Popular without being mainstream, System proves that they are truly the defining voice in metal, or popular music for that matter, in the world today.    Stay Out of the Daylight!    Isaac

0671027344|5.0|Stephen Chobsky's The Perks of Being a Wallflower  is a coming of age story about a High School Freshman Charlie, and his Senior friends. It describes the trials and tribulations of growing up as a modern teenager. I liken this book to Salinger's The Catcher in the Rye. The main difference, is Chobsky uses the idea of letters to a pen-pal to portray his message, while Salinger uses the more traditional method of storytelling.  <br />        The Perks of Being a Wallflower deals with issues that include: rape, drug use, being homosexual in American society, Teenage sex, pregnancy, and a score of others. Due to this, I highly encourage people to read this book.   <br /> I would recommend this book for not only Jr. High and High School students, but parents of these students. The situations that Charlie go through are realistic, but the likelihood of all of them coinciding are remote. The book is a relatively short read, it only took me a couple of hours.

B0007Y4TVU|5.0|\\"Mezmerize\\" is, without a doubt, a spectacular album. System of a Down is back with their brand of faced pased, brain-pouding music that sounds like the band has moved beyond the need for mere musical talent, opting instead for releasing a twisted, schitzophrenic psyche through the instruments. Musically, this album is sound, and although not quite as melodic as Steal This Album, it's highly reminiscent of Toxicity and the original debut in its speed and style. It's true that it's short, as the band allegdges it's only half of a Hypnotize/Mezmerize duo (Hypnotize is due out this fall).  <br /> <br />The only problem to be noted is the lyrical style. It's fairly simplistic. On many of the songs, System of a Down appears to have resorted to mindless reptition of a few lines within the songs. Don't get me wrong: the lyrics are different from song to song, and the style of singing changes to, as Daron Malakian (the guitarist) plays a larger vocal role. However, within a song, things can be a bit repititious at times. The exceptions are B.Y.O.B. and Lost in Hollywood. In case you haven't heard it, that first one is enough to make every other band played near them on the radio sound lazy and slow. The second song is more melodic, vaguely reminiscent of Spiders. <br /> <br />Mezmerize is a great album, and fun to listen to. My only gripes are that lyrical issue mentioned above, and the short length. Not that the lyrics thing is even that bad. With Serj and Daron being on the SOAD ball, you can barely understand them most of the time. <br /> <br />Unless you listen really, really quickly.
0671004107|5.0|Like a lot of Sagan's work, Contact is really about the place of humanity, and life, in the greater reality of the universe.  Are we a random accident of nature or is there a more fundamental meaning behind our existence? <br /> <br />As a novel Contact is an entertaining, but sometimes cumbersome, read.  The payoff is a brilliant little twist at the end, completely absent in the movie.  It is original, delightful and a complete surprise, and by itself it raises a pretty good book onto my short list of personal favorites. <br /> <br />Some readers won't get it, or won't get the significance of it, but those who are fascinated by the big questions and reasonably literate in scientific/mathematical thinking, will stumble upon a hidden little gem here.

0395925037|4.0|Not at all what I expected. I expected a monster spouting hate and ignorance. Instead, I found a very well written autobiography. Hitlers writing style has a lot of flavor to it, and the stories are very intriguing, particularly the ones about his youth and the time he lived in Vienna. What is interesting to me is that he tells his story the way he saw it whether it benefits him or not. He freely admits his faults, as well as his strengths. For example, his sadness at being rejected from art school when, in his mind, he thought he was a very good painter. Or, when he admits his lack of understanding of how labor unions work when confronted by co-workers on a construction site. It is a very interesting book. It is a good study of one particular persons version of sociology.

B0007Y4TVU|3.0|After the jaw-dropping musical achievements of their debut album and Toxicity, and even some parts of Steal This Album, this new disc from SOAD is a disappointment of nearly crushing magnitude. The only consistently successful track here is the complex and brutally ironic antiwar dissertation \\"BYOB,\\" while a few other tracks like \\"The Cocaine Makes Me Feel Like I'm On This Song\\" and \\"Sad Statue\\" show interesting advancements in the SOAD approach. But otherwise we have recycled Iron Maiden riffs, rhythms that lack the military precision of SOAD's previous efforts, and so-called ironic lyrics that are becoming more incoherent than irreverent. And all SOAD fans should avoid \\"Old School Hollywood\\" like the plague - a song so bad it's bad, in which Daron Malakian whines about a celebrity baseball game in which he had to associate with Tony Danza and Frankie Avalon.<br /><br />The main problem here is that this is much less of a group effort, with Daron Malakian dominating the band's sound more and more. Malakian is obviously an outstanding songwriter and has steered the band's course successfully, but he is now building the songs increasingly around his guitar and vocal work, which are not nearly as unique or accomplished as his songwriting. Bassist Shavo Odadjian barely establishes presence on this album, and drummer John Dolmayan has been subdued dramatically (Dolmayan's maximalist work on Toxicity made him one of my favorite modern drummers). The greatest crime here is how Serj Tankian, whose frantic and serious-to-hysterical delivery has made him by far the most unique singer in current rock, has been reduced to handling just half of the lead vocals on this album, and has been pushed aside by Malakian's whiny and reedy singing. Despite any claims of building complex vocal arrangements, System of a Down does not need two lead vocalists, especially when one of them should stick to guitar and admit that he can't hold a candle to the real lead singer. Daron Malakian's reach is really exceeding his grasp, and he has reduced his talented bandmates to session lackeys. Watch for more upcoming side projects from the other three guys. [~doomsdater520~]'s reach is really exceeding his grasp, and he has reduced his talented bandmates to session lackeys. Watch for more upcoming side projects from the other three guys. [~doomsdater520~]
B0007Y4TVU|5.0|In the past, SOAD's albums have had some incredibly brilliant musical and lyrical moments but have also had some very uneven moments.  It almost seemed like they wanted to take a more melodic, eclectic route from the very beginning but for some reason felt compelled to also record the skull-crushing numetal that was expected of artists making their type of music.  Mezmerize is System Of A Down without the uneven moments.  The four-years off have done them good: Co-writers Serj Tankian and Daron Malakian have managed to come up with an entire album of literally soaring melodies and harmonies with great hooks, yet still crush your skull with powerful riffs.  There are also some really great surprises on the album- \\"Radio/Video\\" (my personal favorite) hits you hard with the chorus and launches into ska for the verses.  It's insanely catchy- you can't not sing along with it.  My other favorite is \\"Old School Hollywood\\" which reminds me of (here's an obscure reference that NO ONE is sure to get) early (John Foxx era) Ultravox.  The only song that I'm not really crazy about is \\"This Cocaine Makes Me Feel Like I'm On This Song\\", which just reminds me of all those other songs on previous SOAD albums that I wasn't really crazy about (and also features the line \\"gonorrhea gorgonzola\\".  Venereal cheese?  Thanks for that image.  I WAS eating...).  This is certainly the best SOAD album to date and makes waiting for \\"Hypnotise\\" all that much harder.
B00009W8N2|5.0|Between this album and Bergman's \\"The Seventh Seal\\" what makes the products of that northern land so bleak and so damn beautiful?  Sure, the song titles might bear a little good-natured mockery for Scandanavian Metal cliche (\\"The Twilight is My Robe\\"?  \\"In Mist She Was Standing\\"? \\"Under the Weeping Moon?\\"  With company like this on the track list, even \\"The Forest of October\\" doesn't stand out as particuarly sillily ...well...metal.  But then again even this is hardly as bad as an Immortal album as far as giggles are concerned.)  But every song on this album is absolutely gorgeous.  Most of them can still give me goosebumps.      One of the best features of this album is variety.  Though the songs all run over ten minutes (with the exception of two interludes) they never get dull thanks to constantly shifting melodies, copious clean interludes and some really ripping death metal growling/shredding all blended together into a nice broth of melodic death metal goodness.  In \\"The Twilight is My Robe\\" we hear four accoustic interludes, two with accompanying clean vocals, a great slap bass intro to a killer guitar riff, innumerable awesomely melodic guitar solos and great ripping death growls applenty.  Though the accoustic interludes are more or less ubiquitous, they're so well integrated with the harsher elements of the songs, often brilliantly blended together, actually, that they're an organic part of the music rather than some gimmick.  Though they're generally not included among 'post metal' bands like Isis, the effect is very similar, with the blend of speed and slowness, fury and softness and constantly evolving riffs essentially obliterating any sign of a conventional verse/chorus song structure.    \\"In Mist She Was Standing\\" is an awesome album opener, with a great opening guitar riff that introduces 14 minutes of relentless distorted guitars and death growls, with the standardly well-executed opeth clean/accoustic interlude present about ten minutes in.    \\"Under the Weeping Moon\\" is notable for its particuarly well executed interlude and the manner in which that breaks into some awesomely atmospheric guitar work around the six minute mark.    Even in an album this amazing, the standout tracks are the piano  solo \\"Silouette\\" and \\"The Forest of October,\\" the progressive death song it leads into.  I'd compare them to \\"Embryo\\" and \\"Children of the Grave\\" on Sabbath's MASTER OF REALITY, but while that combination was merely rocking/groovy this one is downright beautiful.  \\"Silouette\\" would stand on its own as a really great, atmospheric piece of piano composition but intertwined with the brutality of \\"The Forest of October\\" it's even better.    I've already mentioned mentioned \\"The Twilight Is My Robe\\" above.    \\"Requiem\\" is a nice accoustic segue into \\"The Apostle in triumph,\\" on this version of the CD, anyway, which also starts with some really nice classically flavored (?) accoustic guitar.    My Arms, Your Hearse admittedly has more emotive force and more direction and focus as an album, and Blackwater Park is more innovative and dissonant (plus it includes \\"Harvest,\\" which is an accomplishment, even for these guys), but \\"Orchid\\" displays great melodies and musicianship and awesome song structure.  I'd say it does so without being meandering, either, at least because it never fails to hold my insterst through all its twists and turns.    I'd recomend this album, and this band, to anyone that enjoys the  intros and interludes on Metallica's two Cliff Burton albums, particuarly the instrumentals, since Opeth's song structures seem to take that more intricate approach to heavy-metal songwriting its logical conclusion.  I'd also recomend it to anyone with a serious appreciation of melody and song structure that isn't -extremely- put off by metal standbyes like distorted guitars and death growls.  Hell, my folk-loving very unmetalhead ex girlfriend really loves this album just because it's so freakin' pretty.

B00005JKQZ|5.0|Russell Crowe deserved every award received for this poignant and sensitive portrayal of John Nash.  In the span of decades we are taken from John's young manhood through old age and watch in wonder as he deals with his profession, his colleagues, his wonderful and loving wife and baby, and his imagined reality, all through the fog of mental illness.  We never once look down on his actions, although the scene with the baby in the bathtub is both horrifying and sobering, and we root for him to somehow pull the tattered fringes of his mind together and find peace within.<br /><br />Crowe's tortured performance along with a superb supporting cast, including Jennifer Connely as his supportive wife, will stay with you long after the last scenes.<br /><br />The score is moving and Ron Howard's direction reminds us why he is one of the best in the movie-making business.

B00008DDSC|5.0|The opening scene of \\"Secretary\\" drops the viewer into the middle of the narrative. In a shot that will be repeated 55 minutes later, Lee carries out a variety of office duties with poise and efficiency --despite the fact that she is wearing a bizarre and uncomfortable-looking restraint that holds her arms straight out at the shoulders. The first time around the scene seems odd, almost repugnant; Lee lopes with unnerving calm to (longtime David Lynch collaborator) Angelo Badalamenti's creepy score around a unsettlingly baroque office. Then, abruptly, a title card: \\"six months earlier\\". The narrative proper begins.     At first, it's unclear what this circuitous opening adds to the story, apart from an element of suspense that might not be if the events unfolded in strict chronological order: the opening scene presents a big \\"What?\\"; we wait anxiously to learn the \\"Why\\". What other purpose this scene might serve becomes clear with its reprise. By then a subtle understanding of its context is possible. The remarkable Maggie Gyllenhaal imbues Lee with such supple humanity that the viewer has become more than sympathetic, and understands how much this long-suffering, unassumingly brave woman is enjoying herself, arm-restraints and all. The scene is no longer unsettling, but celebratory. The scene hasn't changed. Maybe we have. Director Steven Shainberg, on the DVD commentary track, says he hopes that his film will do for S&M what \\"My Beautiful Laundrette\\" did for homosexuality almost 20 years ago-- increase mainstream understanding. Perhaps it will.     On the same commentary track, the film's writer Erin Cressida Wilson says that the uncertain \\"Um.....\\" Lee utters after Edward has administered the first blow in the justly famous spanking scene is Wilson's \\"Favorite line\\". She then chuckles, and modestly refrains from explaining what she means. Why it's good: Although this pivotal scene is fraught with emotion, Lee's tentative \\"Um.....\\" is the only line of dialogue in it that acknowledges, even obliquely, what is taking place. Unlike the painfully verbose, excruciatingly clever screenwriters who currently plague independent film, Wilson realizes that what people say may be only tangentially related to what they mean, or are thinking, or what's happening, and that great feeling may lurk behind the most banal or fragmentary remark. \\"Secretary\\" is one of the strictest, fullest applications of this principle imaginable (Each page of the screenplay must contain one column each for speech and subtext). Never glib, never clever, just smart, \\"Secretary\\" is certainly a comedy of some sort, but it contains nothing that exactly qualifies as a joke. Its minimal dialogue leaves wide expanses in which the actors can and must communicate non-verbally. The leads are up to the task. Gyllenhaal (\\"JILL-in-hall\\") and the always watchable James Spader make adept use of the full actor's arsenal: facial expression, posture -watch Lee's gait change in the course of the film-, verbal pauses and inflection create a world of meaning beneath deceptively mundane, often monosyllabic, dialogue. Tune into these actors' peculiar wavelength and be spellbound.

If the entire movie had been like the one action sequence in the whole movie, this would be a 5-star movie. Avoid at all costs.

B00005T30L|2.0|A film adaptation needn't be a carbon-copy of its source material, but it should capture its essence, or why bother? On this count, \\"Ghost World\\" is an almost complete failure. The scene that comes closest to evoking the Daniel Clowes universe   -- the Bollywood musical extravaganza that opens the film   -- is lifted wholesale from someone else's film. There's something very wrong with that.       The crucial difference between the comic and the movie is that while the comic is deliberately anti-dramatic, the film strains to generate drama and fails.   The film  jumps the shark mainly through  the enlargement of the role of Seymour, who exists in the original Ghost World as some anonymous loser the gals sharpen their claws on (they intercept a personals ad he's placed in which he's summarized his appearance as -- damn your gift for the pathetic detail, Clowes -- \\"bearded windbreaker\\"). Ordinarily, you can count on Steve Buscemi to make any film in which he appears better than it would have been otherwise.  Here, the attention he steals away from the girls' friendship cuts the heart out of the story, which rightly should be: Enid and Rebecca against the world, then, sadly, not even that.     Fatal Mistake Two:  Thora Birch could scarcely be less Enid-like. Her stabs at cool affectlessness are both overplayed and feeble, and Enid would never, ever guffaw at her own jokes. In the comic, Enid is a bundle of insecurities, but still has a convincing way with a put-down. Birch's version couldn't psych out a tub of coleslaw. Worse, this extremely uncharismatic actress has been endowed by the Lord Almighty, or a very ambitious plastic surgeon, with physical attributes that effortlessly upstage her in every shot in which they appear.    Scarlett Johansson does a much better job rendering  the  attitude of boredom and disdain that is the lynchpin of the girls' relationship.   Why couldn't they have dyed this great young actress' hair black and put Enid in capable hands?

B00006AW2P|3.0|The American debut of The Rolling Stones was part of the British Invasion, the wave of UK bands who hit the U.S. in the wake of the Beatles early-1964 breakthrough.  Only a handful of bands would mature and survive, and the best of them were The Rolling Stones.<br />Still, there was no guarantee from listening to this fine album that the Stones would be around.  Eric Burdon of the Animals was a better vocalist than Mick Jagger, the Yardbirds' Eric Clapton then later Jeff Beck and Jimmy Paige had the better guitar attack, and few British bands (beyond The Beatles) wrote their own songs.  That means the London blues bands largely recorded blues songs to fill their albums, and how long could they keep that up?<br />What the Stones did have were attitude.  Jagger's lewd, sneering vocals and Keith Richards' Chuck Berry-influenced guitar were the bedrock of this band from day one.  A third key ingredient was Brian Jones' slide guitar, perhaps the best slide playing east of the Mississippi Delta.<br />The album opens with a stunning remake of Buddy Holly's Not Fade Away.  The Bo Diddley beat makes this song move.  It is fantastic.  The remaining covers are performed fast and furious: Route 66, I Just Want To Make Love To You, Carol (great guitar), and the hilarious Walking The Dog.  The Stones' versions are light years from the earthy, dark originals by Muddy Waters et al, but have an energy that remains infectious 40 years on.  I'm A King Bee features the nastiest slide guitar from 1964.  <br />Of the originals, only Tell Me is worth mentioning.  This slow ballad echoes early-60s soul more than Chicago blues, and features some fine vocal work.  <br />The remaining songs, however, fail to measure up.  Can I Get A Witness is the poorest offering on this album, and left me scrambling for the far superior Marvin Gaye original.  Little By Little and You Can Make It If You Try are unconvincing British imitations of American vocals.<br />Overall, this is a solid set of black American blues &amp; soul performed by a white British band.  I would have awarded NEWEST four stars, but there are only 12 and no bonus tracks.  At least Apple/Parlophone issued the Beatles catalogue at their original 14 songs.  ABKCO - in all their wisdom and greed - have stuck us with these second-rate American incarnations at full price.  No wonder CD burning is rampant.
B00005AAFS|5.0|I first heard Sehnsucht's \\"Du Hast\\" Rammstein in a motel room on MTV.  Not that I like to admit that that was the first time I've ever heard of this band, but Rammstein became an addiction.  They're original, they push the envelope and leave you with a jaw-dropping feeling.  Sehnsucht was the first album I bought, following by Herzeleid, which was their best until Mutter was released.<br /><br />In this album they incorporate an orchestra, blend it magnificently with their trademark piano, unique guitar solos and amazing lyrics.  The only unfortunate part of this album is the release of Links 1 2 3 instead of Sonne.  Had the latter been released first, this album would have been more popular than Sehnsucht.<br /><br />In each song they incorporate an orchestra - sometimes on top of guitar riffs - with amazing lyrics (see Spieluhr, Zwitter, Rein Raus, Sonne, Mutter).  This is one of very few albums you will not get tired of listening to, because each time you listen to it you hear something else that you didn't notice the last time.<br /><br />This album showcases Rammsteins' absolute best yet.  Do not hesitate to add this to your collection.
B00006AW2O|2.0|As the Stones' second album, 12 x 5 is another collection of blues and soul covers with a few originals thrown in.  This time, however, the album was recorded at the famed Chess Studios in Chicago, shrine of the electric blues where Muddy Waters and countless of the Stones' heroes recorded their sides.  The sound is more polished with a heavier bottom end, which was what the Stones wanted.<br />The album kicks off with a strong cover of Chuck Berry's Around and Around then dovetails into the moody Confessin' The Blues, featuring some fine harp playing.  The album then dips into Empty Heart, a one-liner that goes nowhere, and follows with the inferior version of Time Is On My Side (the organ version, not the guitar).  Side one closes with their current single at the time, Good Times Bad Times &amp; It's All Over Now -- the album's highlight even if the latter is a Womack cover.<br />Side 2 is a patchy affair with If You Need Me being the only strong tune.  Susie Q is too short, too fast, while Under The Boardwalk must rank along with My Girl (Flowers album) as the worst cover by the Stones.<br />Again, ABKCO has issued the shorter US version of the longer UK album, yet is charging full price.  No bonus tracks.  While there are some fine moments on this album, it is a patchwork affair and suggests that the Stones were already running out of material for their albums and relying too heavily on borrowed tunes.
B0002XDODU|3.0|This record is a mix between Sehnsucht and Mutter. They take it one step further, and add some harsher guitar riffs and a few flat tones - see Stein Um Stein, Moskau - but that's only my opinion.<br /><br />Reise, Reise is defenately an album to buy if you're used to Rammstein, but I wouldn't suggest it to be your first album. 0385512104|3.0|The upside down poodle on the cover was a clever touch, as some of the autistic children do see things upside down, but are not able to express it.  This book written by a Britisher, Mark Haddon, is so close to life it is unreal.  People who have not experienced contact with these exceptional people do have a distorted opinion.  To some, it's funny; to others, it's sad.  Such is life.  But to those who live daily with such a child see it as a burden, not an easy life, but the child is their flesh and blood and a valued individual.      The one thing a writer must do is to put himself in someone else's shoes.  Christopher, the \\"voice\\" of this novel has Asperger Syndrome, a behavior disorder similar to autism only milder.  He can't understand other people's opinions.  You can never get inside his head.  It's as if a wall is built up to insulate the tender feelings he might have.      Savant Syndrome is a rare condition in which these defective males verge on brilliance, math ability, or genius in the talent and music fields.  Chris (John Francis) Boone has a fantastic memory and math skills.  \\"I know all the countries of the world and their capital cities (I've heard that before) and every prime number up to 7,507.\\"  In the 8th grade, we had a mathematical genius in our small class and the male teacher tried each one of us at the blackboard to see if we could out do him -- none could.  We thought at the time that he was just strange, as math was all he could master.      Chris is a lot like the character portrayed by Dustin Hoffman in the 1988 movie, RAIN MAN.  Here in Knoxville, many such adults ride the buses and have menial jobs.  At one of the malls, I had a strange interaction with one of the children; waiting for a bus, I stood at the door (inside as it was cold out) and heard a mother castigating her young son, \\"Don't run in front of a car, do you hear me -- whatever you do, do not run in front of a car.\\"  He looked over at me; I winked at him and he winked back.  I waved to him, and he waved back.  As he started out the door, he said in a loud,clear voice \\"Good-bye.\\"  His mother grabbed him and yelled, \\"Did you say good-bye\\" two or three times.  He just looked at her perplexed.  I explained what I had done, and she said, \\"But he never talks.\\"  God works in mysterious ways, putting us in particular places for a reason.  You see, I had caught the wrong bus and was waiting for the right one.    At the Green Hills library in Nashville, last Spring, after the children's story hour, I sat on one side of Eric and his father (my son) was on the other reading a kids book to him -- one of his favorites.  I said, \\"Jeff, I am a non-entity to this child,\\" as he was totally unaware that his grandmother was there.  Sometimes, love hurts.    This book was released as a children's book and for adult readers at the same time, and has won many awards.  It is inspirational.

B000002J2B|5.0|Up until this late 1976 release, Genesis displayed isolated snippets of climactic awe that defined their brilliance - yet their albums also contained equal amounts of uneventful, acoustic waste material. This Wind and Wuthering album, however, burst through the scene with a much higher ratio of excitement:dullness. W & W also boasts about the finest sound production on any progressive rock Lp, ever. The album jams (at many points) and yet displays a better, more mature progression of their trademark `storybook' sound. <br /> <br />The highlights of this album are more in the form of complete songs - not occasional moments. \\"Eleventh Earl of Mar\\" is classic. The bold track opens the album and gives a 7-minute feel of hot, red-glowing ash being spread over the landscape. Phil's drumming and vocals are about as rocking as he's ever got. The other gem on this album continues to be favorite among progressive fans: \\"...In That Quiet Earth\\". This instrumental first kicks in as some sort of Jeff Beck-ish, jazz fusion workout, but the momentum quickly builds and pretty soon Phil's tom-toms sound like they are poking right through your speaker! THEN they suddenly shift tempo into a real Fire & Brimstone section, with Tony putting some really rough edges on his synthesizer. The only junk on this album is a short instrumental statement, \\"Wot Gorilla\\", but this little piece of filler material is very easy to just skip over. <br /> <br />Good power and stellar sound production. If you have to choose one Genesis CD out of the entire catalog, let it be this one. You may be surprised at how good it is. <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />  <br /> <br /> <br />

B0002NRRAG|5.0|Madeleine Peyroux's 2nd solo CD is a delight!  I'd loved \\"Dreamland,\\" set it on the shelf for a few years, and had one of those deja vu experiences when one of my music buddies sent me a burned disc of his latest raves which included this wonderful new singer Madeleine Peyroux.  Back to the stacks & voila!  One professional reviewer cited this set produced by Larry Klein (known as the man who actually married Joni Mitchell) as being a more focused set; and stylistically, that may be correct.  The covers here are delightful.  My favorite track is \\"I'll Look Around\\" that has only been recorded a few times with versions by Billie Holiday & Nina Simone.  It's a lovely aching vocal rendition with Scott Amendola's brushes giving this a quintessential torch blues feel.  The Gene Austin \\"Lonesome Road\\" has been a bit more popular cover with big band versions by Tommy Dorsey & Benny Goodman and vocalists Louis Armstrong, Peggy Lee, & Frank Sinatra.  While I do have a couple of these in my collection, I hate to admit that I didn't remember them!  My first reaction was, \\"What a lovely new song!\\"  Peyroux's languid vocals grace the lovely lyric, \\"Look up, look up & greet your maker before Gabriel blows his horn.\\"  Peyroux also nails title track in an exquisite rendition.  When a classic like this has been covered by singers as diverse as Joan Baez, Ray Charles, Fats Domino, Lena Horne, Dinah Washington & Bessie Smith, with whom it is probably most closely identified (at least for me), it's hard to really put the stamp of individuality on it.  However, with Dean Parks' guitar & David Piltch's thumping bass, Madeleine glides through the melody, even giving out a little giggle at one point.  Born in Athens, Georgia, but raised in southern California, Brooklyn & Paris, Peyroux handles the French of \\"J'ai Deux Amours\\" (I Have 2 Loves) like a pro.  Her cover of Bob Dylan's \\"Blood On the Tracks\\" song \\"You're Gonna Make Me Lonesome When You Go\\" is excellent, spotlighting what an excellent composition it is.  [Shawn Colvin does a nice version on her \\"Cover Girl\\" set.]  When she tackles Hank Williams' \\"Weary Blues,\\" it becomes totally transformed.  Her writing effort with Norah Jones' breakthrough songwriter Jesse Harris (\\"Don't Know Why\\") on \\"Don't Wait Too Long\\" is a strong track.  This is an excellent set by a unique vocal interpreter.  Now I have to find \\"Got You On My Mind,\\" her collaboration with William Galison!  Enjoy!ent composition it is.  [Shawn Colvin does a nice version on her \\"Cover Girl\\" set.]  When she tackles Hank Williams' \\"Weary Blues,\\" it becomes totally transformed.  Her writing effort with Norah Jones' breakthrough songwriter Jesse Harris (\\"Don't Know Why\\") on \\"Don't Wait Too Long\\" is a strong track.  This is an excellent set by a unique vocal interpreter.  Now I have to find \\"Got You On My Mind,\\" her collaboration with William Galison!  Enjoy!

B0006ZFQP8|4.0|Recorded in studio by the Staatskapelle, Dresden Orchestra, Carlos Kleiber, conducting, this 4-CD boxed set sounds great and the orchestra is full and with enough Wagnerian depth to satisfy the most critical musicologist. Having said that, the choice exists for those who might prefer Price to Voigt, which would probably be the only distinction. I faulted the other recording for the same error. We know the character is off stage, but the CD is an \\"audio\\" recording, and the echo is a distraction, not an asset. Still, its Tristan und Isolde and Wagner, performed by a strong cast and wonderful orchestra. How can you go wrong?

B000001GQP|5.0|I first heard Carmina Burana in a college production back in Spring of 1965 (end of my freshman year).  Like virtually everybody who hears it for the first time, I was immediately taken with Orff's secular cantata and bought Jochum's FIRST recording on Decca LP (that was a mono recording from the early 1950's - this DG stereo account didn't come along until 1967).  When THIS recording came out, I bought the DG LP and discarded the Decca:  the sonics were MUCH better on the re-make, and the performance sounded more fully realized.    Since then, I have seen two other stagings of Carmina Burana and heard some of the other recordings (Muti, Ozawa, Previn, etc.), but my loyalties remain with this one.  Sure, the stereo sound is a little dated (a slight cut in treble smooths out the edgy highs - all in all, this CD is sonically a considerable improvement on the original LP).  The recording was supervised by Orff himself, Jochum's conducting is rhythmically vigorous and exhilarating, and the soloists all sound just great to me (not perfect, but great is good enough). I still think Janowitz does the \\"In trutina\\" more appealingly than anybody else I've heard.  The only other recording I have kept is the Stokowski (EMI), but that's mainly because of the coupling:  \\"A Pagan Poem\\" by Charles Loeffler, a beautiful work that deserves to be better known.  To my taste, the Jochum recording is preferable to Stokowski's Carmina Burana.    I don't think you can go wrong in buying this one.    Highly recommended.

B0007Y4TVU|3.0|After the untimely retirement of Rage Against the Machine and the monster success of 2001's \\"Toxicity\\", System of a Down became the new standard-bearers of anti-establishment rock.  Their music is very unique, mixing hardcore metal and punk with classical and ethnic elements - you could easily find yourself furiously moshing one second and then doing the Fonz's Russian-kick dance (you know what I mean) the next.  Frontman SerjTankian brings a commanding charisma to the mic, but he also knows when not to take himself too seriously.  His two-part harmonies with guitarist Daron Malakian make beautiful moments, countered with rapid-fire rhyming and full-on screeching.  Lyrical content jumps back and forth between hard-edged socio-political commentary and Zappa-esque theatre of the absurd.  All told, the System modus operandi has set them apart from the sea of sameness flowing out of modern radio today.   <br /> <br />\\"Mezmerize\\" is the first of two System releases slated for this year (its counterpart \\"Hypnotize\\" drops in the Fall), a plan that may have failed this album a bit.  All of the trademark System sounds are here, but the songs themselves don't prop up the album start-to-finish.  You get the uneasy feeling that some of the stronger material from these sessions was held back for \\"Hypnotize\\", allowing lesser tracks make the cut on each.   <br /> <br />Other reviews have written about the more prominent role that Malakian's vocals take this time around and it's true - the trend is very real and apparent after only the first listen.  Even on the two-part harmonies, Malakian seems to be mixed louder than his counterpart.  Malakian is certainly the engine that powers the band by writing most of the material, producing, etc., but Tankian should always be its most prominent personality.  Otherwise, System begins to teeter on a more ordinary sound than they're capable of.   <br /> <br />Highlights include the first single, \\"B.Y.O.B.\\" (Bring Your Own Bombs), an anti-waranthem reminiscent of \\"Chop Suey\\", straightforward rock track \\"Revenga\\", and \\"Violent Pornography\\", a commentary on the state of entertainment, the media and \\"the kind of ---- you see on your TV\\".  The other pre-release track \\"Cigaro\\" and \\"Cocaine Makes Me Feel Like I'm on this Song\\" provide worhty absuridst moments.   <br /> <br />It's unfair to hold up System's subsequent releases to \\"Toxicity\\", which was a masterpiece in the alt-metal genre.  However, the relative fall to \\"Mezmerize\\" is significant enough that it pales even compared to \\"Steal This Disc\\", the package of outtakes from those 2001 sessions.  Hopefully, the upcoming release of \\"Hypnotize\\" will flesh out the deserving tracks from this release into a single comprehensive album more worthy of following up \\"Toxicity\\".

B00079FUI6|5.0|From the moment it first aired, DESPERATE HOUSEWIVES proved to be a ratings phenomenon for its network, ABC. Its pilot was the highest-rated show of that week, and the audience kept growing throughout its first season. The reason for its immediate appeal and success, moreso than anything, was that the show was wickedly twisted, often unpredictable and funny. Though creator Marc Cherry refers to it as a satire of upper-middle-class suburban life, \\"Desperate Housewives\\" functions as a mix of great comedy and pure soap opera. It has mystery and romance, twists and cliffhangers. And it's often very funny.<br /><br />The writing is generally excellent. You can guarantee at least one moment per episode where you'll laugh out loud, while the \\"Mary Alice Young\\" mystery that kicks off the first episode remains compelling throughout the season.<br /><br />To sell it all, the cast of experienced actors is absolutely superb. Teri Hatcher - as the bumbling Susan Mayer - and Marcia Cross - as prim Bree Van De Kamp - give career-best performances. Cross is my personal favorite because she can shift tones from wrenching drama to mocking comedy in one scene, and her plotline thus far is the one with the most meat.<br /><br />Felicity Huffman, who was wonderful in SPORTS NIGHT, plays harried Lynette Scavo with a tremendous amount of intelligence. Eva Longoria is fabulously silly as Gabrielle Solis, a self-involved former model who amuses herself by committing adultery with her teenage gardener.<br /><br />The men in the show are great, as well, particularly Steven Culp as Bree's exasperated husband.<br /><br />The plot keeps you guessing. You'll get sucked into the show almost immediately, and \\"Desperate Housewives\\" has kept up the momentum. It's fantastic.

B0007939NO|5.0|Brigadoon is widely considered as one of Vincente Minnelli's lesser achievements. The critics were somewhat disenchanted that Brigadoon was filmed on a sound stage in Culver City rather than &quot;on location&quot; in Scotland. MGM had not helped matters by actually dispatching Minnelli and Producer Arthur Freed to Scotland to scout for suitable filming locations. MGM, like the other major studios, were finding themselves in somewhat dire financial straits due to competition from television and certain pieces of anti-trust legislation that loosened their monopolistic grip over the entertainment industry. When MGM pulled the plug on the concept of an &quot;on location&quot; shoot (they were well aware of Minnelli's obsession with perfection and expected that he would go well over budget if given a free rein), the entire project became saddled with an image problem. By 1954, movie audiences expected something more than fixed indoor sets and painted scenery, especially from a work so site specific as Brigadoon.<BR>    Minnelli faced other obstacles. Ansco was a cheaper and somewhat inferior colour processing system than Technicolor, which no doubt irritated his refined sensibilities. He also had to come to terms with the new demands of Cinemascope and full stereophonic sound, with somewhat mixed results.<BR>    Even more troubling is that the choreography was in the hands of Gene Kelly, who seemed determined to emphasize the dancing rather than musical  element at the heart of Brigadoon. The two had worked wonderfully together on &quot;An American in Paris&quot;, but on the set of Brigadoon their artistic visions clashed. It is telling that Brigadoon was their last collaboration.<BR>     Critics in the 1950's were also a better informed breed than they were 20 years earlier and they were quick to pounce on certain &quot;inaccuracies&quot;, such as the outrageous blends of tartans, which cerainly would have made any Laird wince, and the suitability of much of Mr. Kelly's choreography; hardly Scottish by a long stretch.<BR>     Yet in spite of these encumberances, I love this film. The painted diaramas are in keeping with the preposterous nature of the storyline, and what beautiful sets they are! Minnelli's artistic flourishes are evident eveywhere, such as the ample plantings of heather which must have caused a state of full employment for local florists. Minnelli&quot;s outstanding contribution to American Film was his refined palette of colour schemes, and in Brigadoon his genius achieves its climax. Make no mistake, Brigadoon is a feast for the eyes.<BR>     The music by Lerner and Loewe is superb, with haunting melodies and stirring choruses. Cyd Charisse, always more celebrated for her dancing than her thespian skills, in Brigadoon achieves her finest hour, even though her singing voice is dubbed. Gene Kelly's type of acting is perhaps an acquired taste, but there is no denying his cat like grace and radiant boyish good looks.<BR>   On the whole, the imperfections of Brigadoon only make it more endearing. It is the one musical I never tire of seeing over and over again.
044022165X|4.0|Rudy Baylor is a young lawyer just starting out in Memphis. He's barely making ends meet and has to exchange mowing lawns for his rent. His first case falls into his lap and it's a chance of a lifetime - an insurance company refuses to pay the medical treatments for a man dying of leukemia. Several problems face Rudy with this case, a few minor things like first passing the bar exam, getting together enough money to even try this case since he's flat broke, and getting the courage to go up against a huge corporation who just happens to have hired the best defense attorney around.<br /><br />John Grisham endures his characters to the reader and makes everyone think Insurance Companies are corrupt and only after profits.  THE RAINMAKER is one of those books that will have the reader cheering against Corporate America and wondering just how many times this type of atrocity has actually happened. Many of Grisham's books make you think about things in real life and wonder just how much is being covered up by big money corporations. This is definitely one of those adventures!<br /><br />THE RAINMAKER is another great book by this writer. Not as good as some of his earlier works, e.g. The Firm, The Pelican Brief, or A Time To Kill, but still a decent read and definitely worth the time spent. It's presented me with a radically different worldview. <br /> <br />Where I would approach a task with the question \\"How do I get this done?\\", Keith approaches it with \\"Who are the people that can help me get this task done?\\"  This is a stunning shift in one's point of reference. B0007Y4TVU|4.0|Oh man, am I happy with this album.  After reading some of the reviews, I wasn't expecting ANYTHING from this cd.  The majority of reviews I read on this website aren't reliable to begin with, so my only recommendation is to go listen to the album yourself.    SOAD's self titled debut is still the best system album, with its raw intensity, unpredictable compositions that never seizes to swing and sway you, Serj's incredible vocals that can't be found in any other album (which I miss more than anything), and.... well, the band just seems to go all out in their self titled debut.    Then came Toxicity.... I loved 'Chop Suey', and that's probably the song that blew this band up more than anything.  Their 2nd effort seemed to have a few more radio friendly songs, but the overall feel of the album was lacking.  I found myself often skipping songs, which was never an issue with the 1st album.  A lot of the energy previously seen from SOAD were gone, and the majority of the songs seemed more like B-sides compared to the incredible self-titled album. Steal this album could've switched a few songs with Toxicity to make their 2nd effort more credible.    Then comes Mezmerize... I understand many of the negative reviews might be derived from the fact that this album is well... different from their previous efforts.    Most notable will be Daron's increased role in singing.  He sounds good harmonizing with Serj, but that's only because he has Serj's strong vocals to cover up for his weaknesses.  When Daron sings by himself, it's a different beast... s***, he sounds like me when I'm singing in the shower.  There's a reason why I'm not on American Idol, but atleast my voice doesn't squeal as much when I sing as Daron's often does.  This is my biggest gripe about this album, and Serj's raw talent and personality is nowhere to be found in Mezmerize that it's a shame.    Other than Daron's few weak vocal points, the rest of the album is simply amazing in showcasing SOAD's growth potential.  More emphasis on melodies and harmonizing are stressed in this album, and as an album as a whole, it has a much more consistent feel than Toxicity.  I can leave it on and not worry about reaching over to skip a song, and each song is done so much better than most of Toxicity.  The unpredictable feel of their debut album is somewhat back, but at the same time, SOAD sounds so different that it completely grants them a NEW album, and a NEW feel that I expect from every successing effort from a band.    Fans are always going to have their favorite album they compare every other albums to.  I can't be surprised they're dissapointed when they find that a new cd doesn't sound like the ones they grew up to love.  But I find it boring if all of the albums for a band sounds the same; great bands usually change up their styles a number of times in the span of their career.  I like this new album because it's different, but at the same time it's CLASSIC System of a Down.

B0007Y4TVU|5.0|System of a Down have been impressing people for almost a decade now, but I don't think that anyone could have predicted that they would hit the peaks that they have reached with the latest offering, \\"Mezmerize\\".  <br />     It is a beautiful, educational trip through the best that music has to offer. The entire album is a trip and has no weak moments. The occasional SOAD listener will know what they are getting themselves into, the only difference stylistically, is the growing presence of guitarist/co-songwriter Daron Malakian. His quirky guitar riffs along with even quirkier vocal expressions is a perfect comliment to the ever-present voice of primary frontman Serj Tankian. <br />     The album begins with a short melodic introduction called Soldier Side, which really gets you in tune with the bands political awareness. Then they get right to the first single, B.Y.O.B. This is a great sample of everything that the band does right, melodic and beautiful at times, screaming, loud and erratic at others. The song continues the political sattire with the anti-war sentiments that include, \\"Why do they always send the poor\\" They move further into the album with great purpose and leave no stone uncovered. The standout tracks have to be \\"Radio/Video\\", \\"Sad Statue\\", and \\"Lost in Hollywood\\". <br />     This album is filled with songs that we will remember for years. This album is a true classic and is by far the album of 2005, so far. It has been a pretty dissapointing year, so this came at a perfect time. <br />      <br />     BOTTOM LINE: 9.5 out of 10 <br />     Masterpiece from beginning to end, the only \\"problem\\" might be the short length of about 38 minutes, but the reason for that might be the best news the music world has ever heard, \\"Mezmerize\\" is the first half of a double album release. We will be able to look forward to the incoming, \\"Hypnotize\\", due out in the Fall this year, to save us yet again. System of a Down, we bow down to you for finally taking over where Rage Against the Machine left us.

B00080Z53O|4.0|Your personal position on euthanasia will probably determine whether or not you consider the life of Ram&oacute;n Sampedro to be inspirational.  But his story as told in &quot;Mar adentro&quot; (&quot;The Sea Inside&quot;) certainly provides food for thought.  Ram&oacute;n became a quadriplegic at the age of 26 and when this 2004 film begins he has spent even more years confined to a bed.  He could be in a wheelchair, but Ram&oacute;n refuses.  What he wants is for the Spanish courts to grant him the right to die.  His reason is that he does not find the life he is living to be one of dignity.  Ram&oacute;n does not judge those who are in a situation similar to his own who want to go on living, but for him life has become unbearable and he wants to have the dignity that he is denied in life by dying.<br />The great irony is that for the most part you would not know this his life was so unbearable to look at Ram&oacute;n (Javier Bardem, in a wonderfully understated and captivating performance).  He is articulate and smiles often, showing both wit and humor in his conversations with others.  Ram&oacute;n can still write, using a pen that he holds in his mouth.  Far from being neglected, his sister-in-law, Manuela (Mabel Rivera), has been taking good care of him, aided by her son, Javi (Tamar Novas).  But his brother, Jos&eacute; (Celso Bugallo), wants Ram&oacute;n to stop talking about wanting to die and their father wonders how a son of his could want to give up on life.  Still, Ram&oacute;n thinks mainly of the empty part of the glass of life and is pushing  his case in court against a legal system that apparently wants nothing to do with him or his thorny issue.<br />What is different at this point in his quest are two women who become involved in Ram&oacute;n's life.  Julia (Belen Rueda), is a lawyer who is suffering from a degenerative disease and he has picked her because he thinks she will be more sympathetic to his cause.  What he does not anticipate is that they would fall in love with each other.  Then there is Rosa (Lola Duenas), a local woman who decides she has to visit him and becomes part of his support group as well, even if articulating her motives is beyond her capability.  The addition of this two women changes things for Ram&oacute;n who insists that the greatest show of love his family and friends can have for him is to allow him to die.  Trapped by the refusal of any one friend to do all that he needs, Ram&oacute;n finds a way to make their piecemeal support enough.<br />&quot;Mar adentro&quot; does a good job of presenting both sides of the issue.  The only party to the dispute that comes out looking bad are the courts, that seem to prefer sidestepping the issue by ruling on technicalities rather than making a direct ruling.  Ultimately, what Ram&oacute;n has going for him is that he is so reasonable.  His anger is usually reserved for Javi on such mundane points of life as the placement of a comma in a sentence, and there is only one night where Ram&oacute;n sinks into the depths of despair and cries out in the night, asking why it is that he wants to die.  But there are other sequences in the film that answer that question, showing through the literal flights of Ram&oacute;n's imagination the maddening limitations of his daily routine.  In the end, Alejandro Amenabar's film does not ask you to either endorse or accept Ram&oacute;n's decision, but simply to understand its rationality.a (Lola Duenas), a local woman who decides she has to visit him and becomes part of his support group as well, even if articulating her motives is beyond her capability.  The addition of this two women changes things for Ramn who insists that the greatest show of love his family and friends can have for him is to allow him to die.  Trapped by the refusal of any one friend to do all that he needs, Ramn finds a way to make their piecemeal support enough.  <br />&quot;Mar adentro&quot; does a good job of presenting both sides of the issue.  The only party to the dispute that comes out looking bad are the courts, that seem to prefer sidestepping the issue by ruling on technicalities rather than making a direct ruling.  Ultimately, what Ramn has going for him is that he is so reasonable.  His anger is usually reserved for Javi on such mundane points of life as the placement of a comma in a sentence, and there is only one night where Ramn sinks into the depths of despair and cries out in the night, asking why it is that he wants to die.  But there are other sequences in the film that answer that question, showing through the literal flights of Ramn's imagination the maddening limitations of his daily routine.  In the end, Alejandro Amenabar's film does not ask you to either endorse or accept Ramn's decision, but simply to understand its rationality.

0316172324|5.0|More detail might have been useful, but overall \\"Blink\\" does a reasonable job of describing and quantifying the once-elusive skill of \\"intuition.\\" Those who don't get it might do well to review Gavin de Becker's \\"Gift of Fear\\" or study the materials and research papers in the annotated bibliography.  <br /> <br />It is often said that muggers take about 7 seconds to size up potential victims. However, potential victims can be equally adept at recognizing threats. I saw this in South Side Pittsburgh a few months ago; a serial armed robber was apprehended because a clerk spotted \\"suspicious behavior\\" from across the street. What was this behavior? It wasn't waving a gun or screaming threats or looking like a character in a Spiderman comic strip with big teeth and a handful of chains and tire irons -- it was his simple failure to look like he had any destination and looking too long and lingering at passersby -- or their pockets and purses.  <br /> <br />\\"Blink\\" does not go into bad guys on the street as de Becker does. Nevertheless, he ranges through brand loyalty, prediction of divorce, and how we see each other -- for good or ill.
